name: feast
description:
Feast is an open source feature store for machine learning. It was developed as a collaboration between Gojek and Google in 2018. Feast aims to:
– Provide scalable and performant access to feature data for ML models during training or serving.
– Provide a consistent view of features for both training and serving.
– Enable re-use of features through discovery, documentation, and metadata tracking.
– Ensures model performance by tracking, validating, and monitoring features in production.
description_good_justification:
Feast is an open-source feature store. It is the fastest path to operationalizing analytic data for model training and online inference
- Operationalize your analytics data
- Ensure consistency across training and serving
- Standardize your data workflows across teams

See more at https://docs.feast.dev/
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/feast-dev/feast/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://github.com/feast-dev/feast/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
- Calls out pre-commit hooks which run many checks including formatting + linting
- Calls out tests 
- Calls out additional best practices through a link to https://docs.feast.dev/project/development-guide

name: versatile-data-kit
description: Versatile Data Kit is a data engineering framework that enables Data Engineers to develop, troubleshoot, deploy, run, and manage data processing workloads.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/wiki/Introduction is the starting point for user documentation, contains links to getting started, installation.
documentation_interface_justification:
It's not really met very well. 
We have https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/vdk-plugins/README.md for plugins 
https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/vdk-core/src/vdk/api/job_input.py for data job
https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/wiki/User-Guide for data jobs as well
And https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/tree/main/projects/control-service/projects/helm_charts/pipelines-control-service for installation

But they are very different places and not easy to find. They should be in a common place in the user documentation somehow.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: All released artifacts (helm chart, python packages) have a version set that follow semver.org
version_tags_justification: We do not use git tags but each artifact. But some components provide git commit when getting version details .SDK has vdk version command which prints git commit and API has /info command which prints git commit.
release_notes_justification:
There are some per project - https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/control-service/CHANGELOG.md

On each release there's https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/releases and process https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-to-make-a-new-vdk-release
release_notes_vulns_justification: Release notes are tracked in https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/releases and security vulnerability when fixed would how there
report_process_justification: Feedback is very welcome via the [GitHub site as issues](https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/issues) or [pull requests](https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/pulls)
report_responses_justification: Yes. Not many have been submitted so far, but we've responded.
enhancement_responses_justification: The project has been responding to enhancement requests.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No external reports so far, so this is vacuously true.
build_justification: The project uses CI as code (Gitlab CI) detailed here: https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
build_common_tools_justification: gradle is used for building Java and  N/A for python.
test_justification:
Junit for java https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/control-service/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing

pytest for python https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/vdk-core/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests
test_invocation_justification:
gradle build (Junit) for java https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/control-service/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing

pytest for python https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/projects/vdk-core/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests
test_most_justification: Code coverage is in range of 70-90% Tracked in Gitlab CI.
test_policy_justification: Required  in each PR and commit: https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/support/git-commit-template.txt#L15
tests_are_added_justification: Tests are required  in each PR and commit: https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/support/git-commit-template.txt#L15
tests_documented_added_justification: Tests are required  in each PR and commit: https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/support/git-commit-template.txt#L15
warnings_strict_justification:
There are pre-commit hooks for python which require passing some basic checks. 
https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/.pre-commit-config.yaml

Missing: no java linting enforcement
crypto_published_justification: The project uses https+standard crypto protocols to communicate with users
crypto_call_justification: https implementation built into its web server
crypto_password_storage_justification: We do not store any user credentials (use Oauth2 for authN/Z)
delivery_mitm_justification: https implementation built into its web server
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
static_analysis_often_justification:
https://app.codacy.com/gh/vmware/versatile-data-kit is run on every commit and Pull Request
https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/.pre-commit-config.yaml also is run on every commit
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not produce any software written in a memory-unsafe language
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Each commit triggers an automated pipeline that tests and releases the components. https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/wiki/Gitlab-CICD
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit
access_continuity_justification: All maintainers of the project have access to key resources https://github.com/vmware/versatile-data-kit/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
build_preserve_debug_justification: CLI provides debug flag, Logging level is overrideable for the server part also.
regression_tests_added50_justification: Followed practice is every bug fix to have regression tests.
two_person_review_justification: 100% of all modifications are reviewed. No PR can be merged without at least single review

floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The [readme](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk#readme) has a small amount of documentation for end-users.
documentation_interface_justification: Some documentation exists for [.NET](https://github.com/TASVideos/BizHawk-ExternalTools/wiki/Development-quickstart) and [Lua](http://tasvideos.org/Bizhawk/LuaFunctions.html) APIs.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: AppVeyor and GitLab CI automatically build when commits are added.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The About dialog in EmuHawk (Help 〉 About) shows the Git commit.
version_semver_justification: Uses pseudo-SemVer: increment of minor version indicates the addition of a new emulator core.
release_notes_justification: Release notes are provided [on TASVideos](http://tasvideos.org/Bizhawk/ReleaseHistory.html) only, not in the downloads.
release_notes_vulns_justification: GitHub repo has [Security page](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk/security/advisories), though it's unlikely to be used. Third-party extensions to EmuHawk are run "at your own risk".
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: By [the published policy](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk/security/policy), security issues should be reported directly to project lead via email.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: By [the published policy](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk/security/policy), security issues should be reported directly to project lead via email.
build_justification: AppVeyor and GitLab CI automatically build when commits are added. How to access their logs and artifacts is described in [the readme](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk#development-builds), and their config is checked-in to the repo.
build_common_tools_justification: Uses `dotnet` CLI, with wrapper scripts in POSIX Shell and BATCH.
test_justification: Test suite is briefly mentioned in [this section](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk#emuhawk-development) of the readme.
test_invocation_justification: Uses `dotnet test`, though it's **NOT** documented in the [readme](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk#readme).
test_policy_justification: YoshiRulz seems to be the only one worried about tests, and is not all that dedicated to them.
warnings_justification: C#'s *nullable reference types* are slowly being propogated through the codebase. GitLab CI runs additional static analysis when running the test suite. This static analysis can also be run manually.
warnings_fixed_justification: 0 warnings on `master` (with quite a few warning categories muted)
warnings_strict_justification: "Fast" CI job (run for each commit) does not include additional static analysis, nor do local builds include it by default.
crypto_published_justification: Excluding third-party extensions, EmuHawk does not communicate over the Internet (except the update checker, which uses the standard mechanism for HTTPS), and does not encrypt data at rest. Cryptographic *hashes* are used for file identification (to enable "per-game hacks"), with the standard mechanisms where available.
delivery_mitm_justification: Release downloads are hosted on GitHub, though they are not signed in any way.
static_analysis_justification: Roslyn Analyzers, including built-in ones, StyleCop, and FxCop, are run in CI.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Applied Roslyn Analyzers include [some checks](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/dotnet/fundamentals/code-analysis/quality-rules/security-warnings) for common security pitfalls.
static_analysis_often_justification: CI with additional static analysis is run weekly.
dynamic_analysis_justification: API surface for automated fuzzing is not apparent. See also [Real-Time Corruptor](https://redscientist.com/rtc) project.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: There are some assertions which are only compiled in Debug configuration.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: GitLab CI also builds branches (of main repo), and AppVeyor also builds branches of forks. See [readme](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk#development-builds).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: [Release downloads](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk/releases) are hosted on GitHub.
installation_common_justification: Executable is "portable", reading and writing files in the directory it's extracted to (for the most part).
documentation_current_justification: While the readme matches the latest release, other fragmented documentation does not.
documentation_achievements_justification: Various badges are shown at the top of the [readme](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk#readme) on GitHub, and on [GitLab](https://gitlab.com/TASVideos/BizHawk).
sites_password_security_justification: Repo / issue tracker are hosted on GitHub. CI management is hosted on AppVeyor/GitLab.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Config from older releases is not importable. Movies aren't really importable either, but that's not feasible.
build_standard_variables_justification: *For now*, build output is a Portable Executable, JIT-compiled.
build_repeatable_justification: MSBuild, even without the r17y SDK extension, is nearly perfectly reproducible, with the exception of timestamps.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Manually installed, or installed from AUR.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Nix expression is WIP. Devs on Windows are vaguely told to use the Visual Studio installer. Devs working on C++ or Rust subprojects are expected to get the extra toolchain(s) themselves.
external_dependencies_justification: Third-party assemblies are either checked-in, or downloaded from NuGet, both declared in MSBuild project files like [this one](https://github.com/TASEmulators/BizHawk/blob/master/src/BizHawk.Client.EmuHawk/BizHawk.Client.EmuHawk.csproj).
dependency_monitoring_justification: Packages on NuGet are checked by GitHub's dependabot. Checked-in assemblies are not.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: The remaining checked-in assemblies are those which could not easily be correlated to a NuGet package.
interfaces_current_justification: While *technically* sitll supported, EmuHawk is a WinForms app targeting .NET Framework, both of which have been superceded.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: GitLab CI always runs test suite.
test_policy_mandated_justification: Not feasible to test UI or emulation, which make up most of the codebase.

name: util-linux
description: Util-linux is a diverse collection of Linux utilities. It provides dmesg and includes tools for working with filesystems, block devices, UUIDs, TTYs, and many other tools.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/util-linux/util-linux/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification: The reference documentation is generated and installed via the build system and is usually available in the form of man pages.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/util-linux/util-linux/blob/master/ChangeLog>.
report_tracker_justification: All the issues are tracked on GitHub.
build_justification: It can be built with Autotools and additionally with meson.
build_common_tools_justification: Both Autotools and meson are common tools for building software projects.
build_floss_tools_justification: Both Autotools and meson are FLOSS tools.
test_justification: The tests are usually run via a script hosted at the same repository. It can be run by simply running `make check`.
test_invocation_justification: make check is a standard way to run project like this.
test_policy_justification: The project uses Coveralls to track test Coverage. If it decreases Coveralls complains and PRs turns red. It's also mentioned in https://github.com/util-linux/util-linux/blob/master/Documentation/howto-tests.txt
warnings_justification: The project is regularly built with -Werror -Wall with both clang and gcc on GitHub. All the issues are addressed almost as soon as they pop up.
warnings_fixed_justification: All the issues are addressed almost as soon as they pop up.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Both Coverity and LGTM do that.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: They are usually fixed in less than a week.
static_analysis_often_justification: LGTM analyzes the repository on every PR and almost every commit and Coverity analyzes it daily at midnight.
dynamic_analysis_justification: The tests are run under ASan and UBsan on every PR and every push event to the master branch using GHActions.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project is fuzzed continuously on OSS-Fuzz. Apart from that CIFuzz is used when PRs are opened to make sure there are no regressions or shallow issues.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: There are a lot of assertions that are enabled by default when the project is built on OSS-Fuzz, CIFuzz and with the sanitizers
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The code is tested using GHActions, Coverity, LGTM, Coveralls and so on.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
implementation_languages: C, Shell, M4, Meson, Yacc, Makefile, Python, Perl

name: security-profiles-operator
description:
The Kubernetes Security Profiles Operator (SPO) is an out-of-tree Kubernetes enhancement which aims to make it easier to use SELinux,
seccomp and AppArmor in Kubernetes clusters.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
The contributing page links back to the Kubernetes community contributing guide, which further explains the requirements for acceptable contributions:

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#getting-started
https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/guide/contributing.md#best-practices
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification:
The project provides the latest information around its external interface and options through the auto-generated YAML files used to deploy it into Kubernetes clusters:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/main/deploy/operator.yaml

CustomResourceTypes created by the project can be observed directly from:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/tree/main/deploy/base/crds

Installation/usage documentation also covers details of the external interface and how to use it:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/main/installation-usage.md
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
The installation documentation explains how to deploy the current version in development (main branch):
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/installation-usage.md
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
The project uses semver, as described on release documentation:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/release.md

The tags also reflects this approach:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/tags
version_tags_justification:
Each release is represented by a tag:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/tags
release_notes_justification:
Each release contains a very detail list of changes per type. It also mentioned what dependencies were created, altered or removed:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/releases/tag/v0.3.0
release_notes_vulns_justification:
The specific release that fixes a CVE would contain a Security section detailing what was fixed, this follows the same approach as the main Kubernetes project:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/releases/tag/v0.3.0
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities were reported since the inception of the project.
test_most_justification:
Most features are covered by tests and we track the test coverage over time to ensure a positive trend in the long term:

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/pull/650#issuecomment-964250312
test_policy_justification:
We have an informal policy around testing and try to enforce by tracking test coverage over time:

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/pull/650#issuecomment-964250312
tests_are_added_justification:
As of 1st December, the code coverage had an increase of over 14% in the last 30 days.

https://app.codecov.io/gh/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator
tests_documented_added_justification:
The test policy is documented and followed by contributors. There is no hard rule in terms of every PR must contain tests, however, the PR template also highlights the need of such practice.

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#contributing-steps
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md
warnings_justification:
`make verify` runs a series of SAST tools against the code base, including golangci-lint.

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/Makefile#L285
warnings_fixed_justification:
This is enforced by running the lint as part of the build process.

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/.github/workflows/build.yml#L18
warnings_strict_justification:
`make verify` would break a build and therefore would impede a change to be merged.

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/Makefile
know_secure_design_justification:
One of the maintainers is a Security Engineer.

https://github.com/pjbgf
know_common_errors_justification:
One of the maintainers is a Security Engineer.

https://github.com/pjbgf
crypto_published_justification: The project does not create its own encryption, but rather relies on golang and kubernetes libraries to leverage cryptography.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The project does not store sensitive information.
crypto_random_justification:
The projects relies on third party software to do such things (i.e. cert manager).

https://github.com/jetstack/cert-manager
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: The project leverages dependabot to patch dependencies as soon as new updates are available.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: The project leverages dependabot to patch dependencies as soon as new updates are available.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Pull requests cannot be merged if the commit failed the linting process.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification:
The application is based in golang, and although there is an intention to add fuzzers to it, it hasn't been done yet.
There is a small proportion (< 1%) of C code for a experimental ebpf implementation, which shall be fuzzed once it is stable.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: No DAST or Fuzzing is currently being executed against the application.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No DAST is currently being executed against the application.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
Each pull-request is assessed through a series of tests that spun up on demand clusters at both GitHub Actions and Kubernetes Test Grid. 

https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/pull/650/checks
https://testgrid.k8s.io/sig-node-security-profiles-operator
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
A Slack channel to further assist contributors and users: https://kubernetes.slack.com/messages/security-profiles-operator
english_justification:
All the documentation is in English:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/installation-usage.md
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/blob/master/release.md

The pull requests are written and answered in English:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/pulls
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
implementation_languages: Go, C, Makefile, Shell, Dockerfile, Nix
maintained_justification:
The project has 4 key maintainers and features are actively being developed:
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/graphs/contributors
https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles-operator/graphs/commit-activity

name: hit_counter
description: Ruby version of that old 90s chestnut, the web-site hit counter.
description_good_justification: Ruby version of that old 90s chestnut, <BLINK>the web-site hit counter</BLINK>.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: The [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) specify the requirements for contributions.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: MIT
documentation_basics_justification: Both a [README](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter#readme) and inline [RDoc documentation](https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/hit_counter/0.1.3) are available.
documentation_interface_justification: Both a [README](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter#readme) and inline [RDoc documentation](https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/hit_counter/0.1.3) document the external interface.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
report_process_justification: Users can file bug reports via [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/issues/new/choose).
warnings_strict_justification: This is a Ruby project and so requires no compilation.
dynamic_analysis_justification: The standard-library URI.parse and standard ActiveModel validators are used to validate both :url and :hits, respectively. Automated testing, moreover, covers some edge cases.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: This project makes no network calls; hardened response headers are up to the client code to apply. Since it isn't compiled, neither will compiler flags. We believe the scope for attack is limited to URI parameters and vulnerabilities in dependencies and Ruby itself. We mitigate the former's risk by normalizing and then validating untrusted input, while we address the latter risks by using Dependabot to patch known vulnerabilities automatically.
hardened_site_justification: We use GitHub, and [securityheaders.io verifies that our sites meet this criterion](https://securityheaders.com/?q=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fivanoblomov%2Fhit_counter&followRedirects=on).
installation_common_justification: Users can uninstall by reversing the installation instructions and using gem uninstall.
build_reproducible_justification: This project is a Ruby gem and so does not require compilation.
dco_justification: The contributing guidelines specify a [DCO](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-certificate-of-origin-dco), while the [PR template](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md) includes the signed-off-by line.
code_of_conduct_justification: The project has adopted the [Ruby Community Conduct Guideline](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).
documentation_current_justification: Complete RDoc documentation is available at [RubyDoc.info](https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/hit_counter).
documentation_achievements_justification: The README displays the [CII badge](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter#hitcounter), among others.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: This project is a Ruby library.
internationalization_justification: This library doesn't generate text for end-users.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Interfaces have been preserved since the first release.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: All vulnerabilities have so far been [reported by Dependabot](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed+author%3Aapp%2Fdependabot).
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: Dependabot automatically addresses known vulnerabilities. Users can also [report ones they find](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/issues/new/choose).
coding_standards_justification: CI [runs rubocop](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yml) which enforces standard Ruby style.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: CI [runs rubocop](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yml) which enforces standard Ruby style.
build_preserve_debug_justification: No build/installation system involving compilation is used since this is a Ruby gem.
build_non_recursive_justification: No build/installation system involving compilation is used since this is a Ruby gem.
build_repeatable_justification: No build/installation system involving compilation is used since this is a Ruby gem.
installation_standard_variables_justific: This project, being a Ruby gem, follows standard conventions.
installation_development_quick_justifica: This project documents [installation steps and support files](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter#hitcounter) in the README and CI runs [standard RSpec](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/actions/workflows/test.yml) for testing.
external_dependencies_justification: All dependencies are maintained by Bundler in a [gemspec](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/hit_counter.gemspec).
dependency_monitoring_justification: Dependabot automatically patches known vulnerabilities by [opening pull requests](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed+author%3Aapp%2Fdependabot) which are promptly merged.
updateable_reused_components_justificati:
1. All dependencies are listed in the gemspec and maintained by Bundler.
2. Dependabot automatically patches known vulnerabilities by [opening pull requests](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed+author%3Aapp%2Fdependabot) which are promptly merged.
interfaces_current_justification: CI [calls rubocop](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/.github/workflows/test.yml), which identifies deprecated/obsolete functions as failures.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: CI invokes RSpec as a GitHub Action and displays results as a [badge in the README](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter#hitcounter).
regression_tests_added50_justification: The [PR template](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md) requires regression tests for bugs, which is enforced by reviewers.
implement_secure_design_justification: The security requirements describe the implemented [secure design principles](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/wiki/Security).
input_validation_justification: Untrusted input is normalized and then validated using `Addressable::URI.parse` and standard ActiveModel validators.
signed_releases_justification: Releases are signed beginning with version 0.1.4; the README documents how to [verify the signature](https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter#security-note).
copyright_per_file_justification:
All original source files include the copyright notice...

https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/lib/hit_counter.rb
https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/spec/lib/hit_counter_spec.rb
license_per_file_justification:
All original source files include the license notice...

https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/lib/hit_counter.rb
https://github.com/ivanoblomov/hit_counter/blob/master/spec/lib/hit_counter_spec.rb
require_2FA_justification: We require two-factor authentication for all organization members and outside collaborators as described in [Requiring two-factor authentication in your organization](https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/keeping-your-organization-secure/requiring-two-factor-authentication-in-your-organization).
test_branch_coverage80_justification: There are no top-to-bottom FLOSS tools available in Ruby which can measure branch coverage. Ruby version 2.5 was the first version that enabled capturing branch coverage, and it was only released on 2017-12-25. Other tools on top of Ruby need to be modified so that they can use this information.
